channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-7405] Enforce PB ser/de for Aggregate protocol and associated ColumnInterpreter user code bits
item.description: Enforce PB ser/de for Aggregate protocol and associated ColumnInterpreter user code bits
item.summary: Enforce PB ser/de for Aggregate protocol and associated ColumnInterpreter user code bits

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Work-in-progress patch. Testing yet to be done.
This patch passes the unit tests in TestAggregateProtocol.

I forgot to note that I made ColumnInterpreter an abstract class. This makes some reflection-related inference possible (e.g. AggregationClient.getPromotedMsgType) which doesn't work if the base class is an interface. Without the inference, there would be additional user APIs to get the types from the user code.

These look generic DD:

+message EmptyMsg

{ +}

+
+message LongMsg

{ + required int64 longMsg = 1; +}

Especially the first. Maybe belongs in hbase.proto?

What is going on here?

  • public <R, S> R max(final byte[] tableName, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S> ci,
    + public <R, S, P extends Message, Q extends Message, T extends Message>
    + R max(final byte[] tableName, final ColumnInterpreter<R, S, P, Q, T> ci,

We have more args P, Q, and T. They extend Message. But I only see Q in the below change in the method:

+ ByteString b = response.getFirstPart(0);
+ Q q = getCellMsgInstance(ci, b);
+ return ci.getCellValueFromProto(q);

Others use T and S. Are the added args doc'd?

The patch looks good but I'm not sure on what we are getting if we commit. Thanks DD.

Pardon my being thick.

Thanks for the review, stack. Responses below:

Especially the first. Maybe belongs in hbase.proto?

Yes, I could put it there.. Will do.

We have more args P, Q, and T. They extend Message. But I only see Q in the below change in the method:
Others use T and S. Are the added args doc'd?

Yeah, true. I did it this way just to have the same signature for all methods. I think this makes it look better than the alternative..

On the javadoc, I think most of it is doc'ed. I'll make a pass over the patch again with the doc in mind.

The patch looks good but I'm not sure on what we are getting if we commit. Thanks DD.

The thing we get is user code deals with PB only. In the earlier iteration of the Aggregate/ColumnInterpreter conversion to use PB (HBASE-6785), I had kept the user code ser/de generic (meaning users could do PB or anything else, and the framework would treat user code bits as opaque bytes and hence the ColumnInterpreter APIs had the ByteString/byte[] signatures). Over in HBASE-6787 (http://bit.ly/Sq56RP), the consensus was to mandate PB in user code as well, and this patch addresses that for Aggregate/ColumnInterpreter. Makes sense?

This message is automatically generated.

The thing we get is user code deals with PB only.

That sounds right (Yeah, decision was made after original implementation). Makes sense.

Yeah, true. I did it this way just to have the same signature for all methods. I think this makes it look better than the alternative..

I'd say depends. See what the javadoc says. On one hand its good to be regular. On other hand, user will be trying to figure what to do w/ the extra unused generics thinking they must be for something – though in their case they do not need them.

I'd say depends. See what the javadoc says. On one hand its good to be regular. On other hand, user will be trying to figure what to do w/ the extra unused generics thinking they must be for something – though in their case they do not need them.

I think I can address this concern by moving the generics "<R, S, P extends Message, Q extends Message, T extends Message>" to the class level... Will update the patch.

This patch mainly adds some javadoc around the new params added to the ColumnInterpreter class.

This patch doesn't change the signature of the methods in the AggregateClient (Stack's last comment). The reason being that the ColumnInterpreter is typed with those types, and the ColumnInterpreter is passed as argument to the AggregateClient methods.

I thought that I could fix this by moving the generics declaration to the AggregateClient class declaration. That works but unfortunately requires all the callers to do explicit typecasts for the expected return types of the AggregateClient methods (somewhat odd but yeah..), making the whole thing look ugly.

On the plus side:
Users are mostly going to only provide custom implementations for the ColumnInterpreter class, and, this sort of a long'ish generics signature is not required for the ColumnInterpreter methods.
Not sure why the last patch got uploaded twice. Deleted one of them.

This message is automatically generated.
The doc helps. Thanks. I'm still a bit lost on what is going on but patch looks good to me. Let me ask the man what he thinks.... Gary Helmling What you think boss?

So the change of ColumnInterpreter from interface to abstract class is so that you can do the ParameterizedType.getActualTypeArguments() stuff? Makes sense to me. I was trying to figure out if you could avoid the AggregateImplementation.constructorColumnInterpreterFromRequest() reflection by using something like Message.getDefaultInstance(), but you'd just wind up doing the reflection in another place. Doing the parseFrom as you currently do seems just as valid. Would it make sense to bundle up the reflection bits in a ProtobufUtil method though?

The ColumnInterpreter defined interface still makes my head hurt a bit, and the additional types in the definition are ugly, but I think it's still a win that anyone wanting to implement this can deal with Message types and the serialization is done transparently.

These four methods in ColumnInterpreter do leave me feeling like they're two copies of the same interface:




  /**

   * This method gets the PB message corresponding to the cell type

   * @param t

   * @return the PB message for the cell-type instance

   */

  public abstract Q getProtoForCellType(T t);



  /**

   * This method gets the PB message corresponding to the cell type

   * @param q

   * @return the cell-type instance from the PB message

   */

  public abstract T getCellValueFromProto(Q q);



  /**

   * This method gets the PB message corresponding to the promoted type

   * @param s

   * @return the PB message for the promoted-type instance

   */

  public abstract R getProtoForPromotedType(S s);



  /**

   * This method gets the promoted type from the proto message

   * @param r

   * @return the promoted-type instance from the PB message

   */

  public abstract S getPromotedValueFromProto(R r);

I'm trying to figure out if extracting that actually simplifies things though. Let me play with that aspect a bit tonight and see if I come up with anything useful.

I tried extracting a single interface for the value <-> PB message conversions:


public interface TypeSerializer<T, Q extends Message> {



  public abstract Q wrap(T t);



  public abstract T unwrap(Q q);

}

But this didn't really pan out. It saves some complexity in the ColumnInterpreter type signature (the additional Q and R are not required on that class) and avoids some minor duplication in the code, but it then adds more complexity in having potentially 3 client classes to send to the server (CI, serializer for cell type and serializer for promoted type). So I don't think there is any net benefit. Sorry for the diversion.

I'd say let's stick with DD's v3 patch. The one change I think worth making is extracting out the reflection code to do Message.parseFrom(), which is currently repeated several times in AggregationClient and AggregateImplementation, into ProtobufUtil.
Thanks Gary Helmling for playing with the patch (and glad to know that you validated my approach). I'll update the patch with the reflection code move to ProtobufUtil.
Okay here is the updated patch with the comments addressed...

Gary Helmling:
Do you have further comments for this JIRA ?

+   * Get an instance of the generic argument passed to a class

...

+   * @return

...

+  T getParsedGenericInstance(Class<?> runtimeClass, int position, ByteString b)

'generic argument' should be 'generic type parameter', right ?
Please fill out what gets returned - this would be one of the reasons for javadoc warning above.
Ted Yu Taking a look now...

Just a couple documentation nits below. If you fix up these, I'm +1 on the v5 patch.

In ColumnInterpreter, javadoc for getRequestData() needs to be updated for change to initialize() signature. Should be:

-   * will pass this to the {@link #initialize(ByteString)}

+   * will pass this to the {@link #initialize(P)}

In AggregateImplementation, add doc for each type parameter in class javadoc:


 /**

  * A concrete AggregateProtocol implementation. Its system level coprocessor

  * that computes the aggregate function at a region level.

+ * {@link ColumnInterpreter} has the explanation for the params.

  * @param <T>

  * @param <S>

+ * @param <P>

+ * @param <Q>

+ * @param <R>

  */
Ok this addresses the doc comments from Gary Helmling and Ted Yu.

w.r.t. javadoc warning:

...

Looks like the type parameter P was not recognized.

Removed the 'P' argument from the javadoc . Manually ran the 'mvn javadoc' command, and verified this doesn't cause any javadoc issue..
